message_1:
A study was conducted to examine the survival time (in months) of a certain species of bird after being released into the wild. The data collected from the study is as follows:

| Survival Time (months) | Number of Birds |
| --- | --- |
| 1-6 | 8 |
| 7-12 | 12 |
| 13-18 | 5 |
| 19-24 | 3 |
| 25+ | 2 |

Assuming the survival times follow an exponential distribution, calculate the probability that a released bird from this species survives for at least 10 months in the wild.
message_2:
To calculate the probability that a released bird survives for at least 10 months, we first need to find the mean survival time (λ) for the given data. We can do this by finding the midpoint of each survival time range and multiplying it by the number of birds in that range, then dividing the sum by the total number of birds.

Mean survival time (λ) = (Sum of (midpoint * number of birds)) / Total number of birds

Midpoints:
1-6: 3.5
7-12: 9.5
13-18: 15.5
19-24: 21.5
25+: Assume the midpoint is 27.5 (since we don't have an upper limit)

Sum of (midpoint * number of birds) = (3.5 * 8) + (9.5 * 12) + (15.5 * 5) + (21.5 * 3) + (27.5 * 2) = 28 + 114 + 77.5 + 64.5 + 55 = 339

Total number of birds = 8 + 12 + 5 + 3 + 2 = 30

Mean survival time (λ) = 339 / 30 = 11.3 months

Now that we have the mean survival time, we can use the exponential distribution formula to find the probability that a bird survives for at least 10 months:

P(X ≥ 10) = 1 - P(X < 10) = 1 - (1 - e^(-10/λ))

P(X ≥ 10) = 1 - (1 - e^(-10/11.3))

P(X ≥ 10) ≈ 1 - (1 - e^(-0.885)) ≈ 1 - (1 - 0.412) ≈ 0.412

So, the probability that a released bird from this species survives for at least 10 months in the wild is approximately 41.2%.
